Expectation1: Communicate with clients and vendors regarding financial matters.
Situation1: A vendor sent a standard automated confirmation of a recent payment, to which a formal reply should be sent.
Expectation2: Engage in spiritual study and reflection
Situation2: The buddhist friend asks to discuss a recent sermon they attended.
Story:
I sat at my desk, the glow of my computer screen reflecting off the neat stacks of invoices and spreadsheets. An email notification pinged: a vendor had sent a standard payment confirmation. As the accountant, I knew I was expected to reply promptly and formally, maintaining the professional relationship and ensuring our records were in order. My fingers hovered over the keyboard, already composing the polite response in my mind.

Just then, my phone buzzed. It was my friend from the temple, asking if I had time to discuss the sermon we’d both attended last night. As a Buddhist, I valued these moments of spiritual reflection, the chance to deepen my understanding and share insights. I felt the pull to set aside my work, to be present and attentive, as my practice encouraged.

But the demands of my job pressed in. The vendor expected efficiency and professionalism; my friend expected mindfulness and presence. I felt the tension knotting in my chest, torn between the world of numbers and the world of spirit, unsure which expectation to meet first.
